metadata.case_name: M/s. Munshi Lal Beni Ram Glass Works v. Lal Khan & Ors.

facts.text: In June 1956 there was a strike in the glass factory of the appellant, M/s. Munshi Lal Beni Ram Glass Works, at Ferozabad. As a result the factory was closed down for some time.

In August 1956 a settlement was reached with the workers and it became possible to reassume operations from August 31, 1956. The workers were asked to report personally, latest by August 26, 1956, to show their willingness to work.

According to the appellant, Lal Khan, one of the workers, failed to register his willingness to work before the appointed day, and indeed he did not care to report in spite of a messenger having been sent to him requiring his attendance.
In his place one Jang Jit was thereupon employed and intimation of this fact duly sent to Lal Khan.

This gave rise to a controversy between Lal Khan and the employers with the result that the State Government purporting to act under ss. 3, 4 and 8 of U.P. Industrial Disputes Act referred the following dispute to the Adjudicator: Whether the employers have wrongly and/or unjustifiably refused employment to Shri Lal Khan with effect from 28/29th August, 1956?

Soon after the reference the appellant presented a writ petition in the Allahabad High Court, C.W. No. 899 of 1957 challenging its validity principally on the ground that there was no industrial dispute within the contemplation of the Industrial Disputes Act.
As interim stay of the proceedings was declined, the proceedings before the adjudicator continued and on December 31, 1957 the adjudicator gave his award.
This was followed by an order of the State Government dated January 28, 1958 enforcing the award under ss. 3 and 6(2) of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

The award and the order of the State Government were also challenged by the appellant by means of a writ petition in the High Court C.W. No. 1025 of 1958. Though principally in this writ petition the power of the State Government to enforce the award was questioned, challenge to the order of reference was also reiterated.

A learned Single Judge allowed this later writ petition holding that the State Government had no power to enforce the award in question. According to the learned Single Judge the old s.6 having been replaced by a new section 6 by U.P. Act 1 of 1957, it was not a case of repeal simpliciter and therefore old s. 6 could not be resorted to by relying on s.6(e) of the General Clauses Act.

On the matter having been taken on special appeal a Division Bench of the High Court following its earlier decision reported as Central Distillery and Chemical Works Ltd. Meerut v. State of U.P. reversed the order of the learned Single Judge and dismissed the writ petition.
Appeals to Supreme Court on certificate of fitness from Allahabad High Court judgment and decree dated May 7, 1964 in Special Appeals Nos. 77 and 118 of 1960.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.6A as mentioned in s.16 of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1956 (U.P. Act 1 of 1957) as amended by U.P. Industrial Disputes Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions Act XXIII of 1957, refers to s.6A as it stood in U.P. Act XXVIII of 1947 prior to its amendment by U.P. Act 1 of 1957 or as it emerged after the said amendment.

Whether the proceeding in question pending with the adjudicator could be considered to be pending with the State Government and the State Government could give effect to the decision of the adjudicator under s.16.
Whether without resort to s.17 of U.P. Act No. 1 of 1957 the award could not be enforced.
Whether the decision of the adjudicator is not an award as defined in s.2(c) of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act as amended by U.P. Act No. 1 of 1957.

Whether old s.6 of the Principal Act having not been repealed simpliciter, but having been replaced by a new section 6 by U.P. Act 1 of 1957, the principle underlying s.6(e) of the General Clauses Act cannot be attracted.

petitioner_arguments.text: There was no industrial dispute within the contemplation of the Industrial Disputes Act.

The amendment of s.16 was retrospective so as to date back to April 16, 1957 when s.16 itself was originally enacted, indicates that s.6A as it existed prior to April 16, 1957 was intended to be kept alive.

The proceeding in question pending with the adjudicator could not be considered to be pending with the State Government and the State Government could not give effect to the decision of the adjudicator under s.16.
Without resort to s.17 of U.P. Act No. 1 of 1957 the award could not be enforced.
The decision of the adjudicator is not an award as defined in s.2(c) of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act as amended by U.P. Act No. 1 of 1957.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(c) of U.P. Industrial Disputes Act as amended

petitioner_arguments.text: Old s.6 having been replaced by a new section 6 by U.P. Act 1 of 1957, it was not a case of repeal simpliciter and therefore old s.6 could not be resorted to by relying on s.6(e) of the General Clauses Act.

respondent_arguments.text: Section 16 refers to s.6A as amended by U.P. Act 1 of 1957.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.16 U.P. Act 1 of 1957 as amended by U.P. Act XXIII of 1957; Central Distillery and Chemical Works Ltd. Meerut v. State of U.P.

court_reasoning.text: Prima facie this amendment in s.16 made in November, 1957 should be referable to section 6-A in the form in which it existed on the date of the enforcement of the amending Act U.P. Act XXIII of 1957.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The amendment in s.16 made in November 1957 refers to the then existing s.6A.

court_reasoning.text: To specifically incorporate s.6A in s.16 in this situation is suggestive of the intention of the Legislature to extend the amended s.6A to the proceedings contemplated by s.16.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.16 designed to save pending proceedings; specific incorporation suggests amended s.6A applies.

court_reasoning.text: The construction placed on this provision by the two Benches of the Allahabad High Court is clearly erroneous justifying reversal? No, the court upholds Division Bench.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not satisfied that High Court view erroneous; to uphold Single Judge would render awards unenforceable.

court_reasoning.text: The proceeding in question was clearly pending before the adjudicator as contemplated by s.16. The adjudicator could plainly proceed to adjudicate upon the dispute. On his award the provisions of s.6A would be attracted and thereunder the State Government could enforce it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proceeding pending before adjudicator; s.6A applies post-adjudication.

court_reasoning.text: s.17 only provides for delegated legislation in certain circumstances and resort to s.17 is not essential, or a condition precedent for enforcing the awards.
If U.P. Act No. 1 of 1957 is excluded from its application to pending proceeding under s.16 then the word 'award' has to be liberally construed and so construed it would be covered by s.6A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Liberal construction of 'award' covers adjudicator's decision.

court_reasoning.text: Section 6 would seem to us to apply to a case of repeal even if there is a simultaneous enactment unless a contrary intention appears from the new enactment. Whenever there is a repeal of an enactment, the consequences laid down in section 6 of the General Clauses Act will follow unless a different intention appears.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.6 General Clauses Act applies unless new Act shows contrary intention; disapproves Single Judge view.

holdings.text: s.16 of U.P. Act 1 of 1957 refers to s.6A as amended by U.P. Act 1 of 1957.
Proceeding pending before adjudicator under s.16; State Government can enforce award under amended s.6A.
No need to resort to s.17 for enforcement.
Adjudicator's decision is an 'award' liberally construed.
s.6(e) General Clauses Act applies to replacement/repeal unless contrary intention.

outcome.summary: The appeals challenging the Allahabad High Court's Division Bench decision upholding the enforceability of the adjudicator's award under the amended provisions are dismissed. The Supreme Court holds that s.16 refers to the amended s.6A, allowing the State Government to enforce the award.

key_quotes.text: The short question, the determination of which is decisive of these appeals, is whether s.6A as mentioned in s.16 of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1956 (U.P. Act 1 of 1957) ... refers to s.6A as it stood ... prior to its amendment ... or as it emerged after the said amendment.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Prima facie this amendment in s. 16 made in November, 1957 should be referable to section 6-A in the form in which it existed on the date of the enforcement of the amending Act in question (U.P. Act XXIII of 1957).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to interpreting temporal application of amendment.

key_quotes.text: Section 6 would seem to us to apply to a case of repeal even if there is a simultaneous enactment unless a contrary intention appears from the new enactment.

key_quotes.text: The result is that these appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
